article_title: Mayor Ed Lee now wants police to have stun guns soon
article_text:
Mayor Ed Lee now wants police to have stun guns soon

Photo: Lea Suzuki, The Chronicle Chief Greg Suhr’s 2013 proposal to arm the SFPD with stun guns...

Mayor Ed Lee, reeling from the ongoing fallout over the Mario Woods fatal police shooting, has moved from wanting an “open conversation” about the use of stun guns to pushing to get them in the hands of officers ASAP.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Matier & Ross
article_metadata.description: Mayor Ed Lee, reeling from the ongoing fallout over the Mario Woods fatal police shooting, has moved from wanting an “open conversation” about the use of stun guns to pushing to get them in the hands of officers ASAP.  The mayor phoned both Police Commission President Suzy Loftus and Police Chief Greg Suhr this week, asking them to start drawing up plans immediately to purchase and train officers on the use of the stun guns — a weapon that had been rejected twice by the commission over concerns about their safety and effectiveness.  The move underscores the ongoing tensions over the shooting of Woods, a recently released convict who officers say stabbed someone before being confronted and shot by police in the Bayview on Dec. 2.  A Labor Council resolution said that if the facts warranted it, the district attorney “should prosecute the police who fired their guns to the fullest extent of the law, up to and including charging them with murder.”  All the heat brought a quick retort from Police Officers Association President Martin Halloran, who said Woods “was also recently released from prison, had allegedly stabbed someone 30 minutes earlier, and was using the knife to threaten a police officer.”  The prestigious Stanford Health Care  medical center was among 15 Bay Area hospitals to have their federal Medicare payments reduced next year for allegedly failing to keep potentially avoidable patient infections and other injuries in check.  Others on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid penalty list include John Muir Medical Center in Walnut Creek, California Pacific Medical Center’s St. Luke’s and Davies campuses in San Francisco, and Kasier Permanente hospitals in Antioch, Walnut Creek, San Jose, Oakland and  Richmond.  Asked for comment, Dr. Rajneesh Behal, Stanford Health’s chief quality officer, acknowledged that rates for surgical, blood and urinary tract infections that are important quality and safety indicators’’ were higher than the federal standard between 2012 and 2014.  Former Attorney General and state Treasurer Bill Lockyer and his wife, Nadia — whose sex and drug scandal cost her her job as an Alameda County supervisor and nearly ended their marriage — have just welcomed the birth of twin boys to the family.  Nadia Lockyer resigned as a county supervisor in 2012 after a meth-fueled affair with a South Bay man, who allegedly assaulted her in a motel room and tried to blackmail her with an X-rated tape he had shot of the two.
